title: How to Find Out Who Has Blocked You on Facebook: Top Signs

steps.title: Open Facebook.
steps.content: Open Facebook. You can use the Facebook app or the Facebook website in a browser. This will open your News Feed if you're already logged into Facebook. If you aren't logged in , enter your email address and password before continuing.

steps.title: Select the search bar.
steps.content: Select the search bar. Tap or click the white box that says "Search" at the top of the page.

steps.title: Enter the person's name.
steps.content: Enter the person's name. Type in the name of the person whom you suspect blocked you, then tap See results for [name] (mobile) or press Enter (desktop).

steps.title: Select the People tab.
steps.content: Select the People tab. It's at the top of the page. Sometimes people who have blocked you or deleted their accounts will appear in the All tab of the search results, but these people will not show up in the People tab.

steps.title: Look for the person's profile.
steps.content: Look for the person's profile. If you can see the profile while on the People tab of the search results, the person's profile is still active, meaning that they just unfriended you. If you can't find the profile, they may have deleted their account or blocked you from seeing it; however, they may also have set their privacy settings high enough that you can't search for them on Facebook. If you do see the account, try tapping or clicking it. You'll be able to see a limited view of the profile if you aren't blocked. To confirm, ask a mutual friend to search for the person. If they see the user and you don't, it's very likely you're blocked by them.

steps.title: Open Facebook.
steps.content: Open Facebook. You can use the Facebook app or the Facebook website in a browser. This will open your News Feed if you're already logged into Facebook. If you aren't logged in, enter your email address and password before continuing.

steps.title: Go to a friend's profile page.
steps.content: Go to a friend's profile page. This must be a friend who is currently also friends with the person whom you think blocked you. Select the Search bar . Enter your friend's name. Select their name in the drop-down box. Select their profile image.

steps.title: Select the Friends tab.
steps.content: Select the Friends tab. It's below the grid of photos near the top of their profile (mobile) or directly below their cover photo (desktop).

steps.title: Select the search bar.
steps.content: Select the search bar. Tap or click the "Search Friends" bar at the top of the screen (mobile) or in the upper-right side of the Friends page (desktop).

steps.title: Enter the person's name.
steps.content: Enter the person's name. Type in the name of the person whom you think blocked you. After a moment, the friends list should refresh with results.

steps.title: Look for the person's name.
steps.content: Look for the person's name. If you see the person's name and profile picture in the results, they haven't blocked you. If you don't see the name and picture here, the person has either blocked you or deleted their account. One way to find out is by asking the friend whose page you're on to verify the account's existence.

steps.title: Open the Facebook website.
steps.content: Open the Facebook website . This will open your News Feed if you're already logged into Facebook. If you aren't logged in, enter your email address and password in the top-right side of the page before continuing. This method only works if you and the person whom you suspect blocked you had at least a one-message conversation with each other. You'll need to use the Facebook website version of Messenger , since the mobile app occasionally still shows blocked accounts.

steps.title: Click the Messenger icon.
steps.content: Click the Messenger icon. It's a speech bubble-shaped icon with a lightning bolt in it. You'll find this in the top-right side of the page. Clicking it prompts a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click the diagonal arrow icon.
steps.content: Click the diagonal arrow icon. This is in the top-right corner, next to the three-dots icon. The Messenger page will open.

steps.title: Select the conversation.
steps.content: Select the conversation. Click the conversation with the person whom you think blocked you. You'll find it in the left-hand column of conversations. You may have to scroll down through this column to find the conversation.

steps.title: Click ⓘ.
steps.content: Click ⓘ . It's in the upper-right side of the conversation window. Clicking it will open a panel on the right side.

steps.title: Look for a link to their profile.
steps.content: Look for a link to their profile. If you can't find a link in the sidebar below the "Facebook Profile" heading, you know that they did one of the following: They blocked you. When someone blocks you, you can't reply to their messages or visit their profile. They deleted their account. Unfortunately, the exact same thing happens when someone deletes their account.

steps.title: Create a new post
steps.content: Create a new post on Facebook. When you're blocked on Facebook, you won't be able to tag the user in any post.

steps.title: Tag your friend.
steps.content: Tag your friend. To tag someone on Facebook, start typing their name in the description. If you're using a photo post, you'll need to select Edit > Tag photo > select their name. If you don't see the user pop up, it's likely that they have blocked you.

steps.title: Create a new event
steps.content: Create a new event on Facebook. If you've been blocked on Facebook, you won't be able to invite them to any events. If you don't want to create an event, you can use an existing event.

steps.title: Try to invite your friend.
steps.content: Try to invite your friend. Select Invite Friends in the Go with friends section. You may need to select the three-dots icon to see it. Type the user's name. If you don't see the user pop up, it's likely that they have blocked you.

steps.title: Ask a mutual friend.
steps.content: Ask a mutual friend. Once you've determined that you can't access the account of the person whom you suspect blocked you, contact a friend of yours who was also a friend of the other person and ask them if the person's account is still live. If they confirm that the account is still active, you know you've been blocked. This is the only way to ensure that you've been blocked (or haven't been blocked) without contacting the person directly, but some will consider it to be an invasion of privacy.

steps.title: Check other social media.
steps.content: Check other social media. If you follow the person on Twitter , Pinterest, Tumblr, or some other social media site, check to see if you suddenly can't find their account. This might indicate that they've blocked you here as well. Alternatively, look for an indication that they deleted their Facebook page. Many people will announce that they have closed their Facebook account on alternate social media.

steps.title: Contact the person directly.
steps.content: Contact the person directly. Ultimately, the only way to be sure that someone has blocked you is by asking them directly. If you choose to do this, make sure it isn't in a threatening or abrasive manner. You must also be prepared to hear that they have indeed blocked you, however hard that may be to hear. Only do this as a last resort—if a long-term friend has blocked you, for example, it might be worth talking to them to try to salvage the relationship. Otherwise, it might be best to take the hint and move on.

steps.title: If you're blocked on Facebook, you won't be able to interact with that user.
steps.content: If you're blocked on Facebook, you won't be able to interact with that user. You won't see any of the user's posts, comments, or likes. You also can't leave any posts or comments on their profile. It prevents all interactions with the user who blocked you. The only way to get these features back is to be unblocked by the user .
